title: How to start my writing career - Quora

response.answer_text: You are more likely to be struck by lightning than to be able to make a living at writing from the very beginning. When you start, you will suck. No one has ever been a good writer without writing about a million words of crap first. You have to learn how to write well by writing a lot and studying writing. This will take years. Of all of the members of the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America, only about 10% make a living from writing. Only about half of the ones making a living from writing are making a living from writing fiction exclusively. The odds are worse than that for screenplay writing. Get a day job that doesn’t suck; there is nothing harder to do than to sit down to write after a day so exhausting that your brain has turned off. This is the job you are going to be having for a while, so make sure it’s something that doesn’t make you want to open a vein rather than go to work. If you are really serious about wanting to make a living from writing, decide, right now, what the minimum amount you can live on is, because that is probably what you’ll be doing for years and years. Learn how to make and stick to a strict budget. If you are really serious about wanting to make a living from writing, you will be sacrificing your social life. You will not be able to play games, hang with friends, go out for drinks, go to the movies, watch the Big Game, or watch television, much less binge. You will be writing every hour before or after work (some people write better when they first get up, some write better after work) and every weekend, or whatever free days you have. There is an entire 10 year swath of popular culture I know nothing about, because that is what I was doing. You will be ready to quit that day-job and try full-time writing when you have five published books or screenplays that someone else paid you for, each one has paid better than the last, you have contracts in hand for three more books or screenplays, and you have a year and a half of expenses in the bank. Why the bank account? Because shit goes wrong, and without that cushion you could wind up unable to keep the lights on. You might decide that you can’t do all of that. That’s fine. Remember what I just said, only ten percent of most writers write full time for a living. There’s no shame in being part of the ninety percent.

I would start by reading Stephen King's excellent "On Writing." It's about the best guide book out there for aspiring writers. You should know that the business side of writing is always tough no matter what level you're at. What improves over time is your craft. The best writers are voracious readers. Also, you have to write every day. Hobbyists wait around for inspiration to strike but professionals can't afford such a luxury. Another reason you must write every day: good days of writing often result from previous good days when you're on a roll, but they can also result from a bad day of writing when everything feels clunky and expository and your output is low. Unfortunately, good days never come from a previous day of not writing. Essentially, writing is like a muscle and requires constant exercise (or exorcise!) and training.  When you've had a good day, stop a page before you complete the chapter or scene. Leave that section for tomorrow so you can pickup where you left off and start on roll. Early on, I attended many writers' groups that were invaluable to the process. Don't worry about someone else stealing your ideas because everyone in the room is secretly thinking their ideas are brilliant and yours are less so. I also had a system of five trusted readers to vet a script or manuscript. Three is too few opinions and seven is too many. Odd numbers are better for tie-breaker purposes when you're looking for people to weigh in on a specific story element. Finally, the essence of professional writing is rewriting. I've been involved with projects that required dozens of drafts before they appeared on screen. Agents, publishers, producers or studio executives will be looking to see how you handle receiving notes for these rewrites. Even the worst comments and suggestions I've received usually resulted from a structural flaw in the story. Finally, if you sublimate your ego in the service of the work, you can accomplish wonderful things and other creatives will want to collaborate with you.  Good luck.

Writing professionally can be both exciting and rewarding. However, it is important to realize that writing for a living can be a challenging career choice. The options for professional writers are numerous and varied, but all require extensive knowledge and skills, as well as years of actual writing experience. Anyone seriously considering the life of a professional writer must answer the following questions for themselves: What style of writing am I best at and who will hire me to do it? Do I need a formal education in writing to succeed? How do I showcase my talents to potential employers or clients? Do I want to work at home as a freelancer or do I prefer a more traditional employment environment?Following things to be considered before pursuing a career in writing. THINK ABOUT YOUR SPECIALTY:Probably no other profession offers more career options than writing. The variety of career paths available for a professional writer is almost limitless. Choosing the right one requires an honest assessment of one’s specific talents, creativity and skills. Not all professional writers are novelists. In fact, the vast majority of professionals make a living writing non-fiction for businesses or publications. Some of the most popular and lucrative writing fields include: Article WritersNewspapers, magazines or websites hire article writers to research and pen short, nonfiction pieces on specific topics. Some writers specialize in subjects such as food, travel, politics, local issues and more. Article writers may be employed as staff writers or work as freelancers.CopywritersCopywriters write copy, that is, text for commercial advertisements and other marketing-related materials. Copywriters must be able to write concisely, holding the attention of a potential customer, leading to the purchase of the subject product or service. Copywriters receive no personal credit, but the best writers work consistently and for good pay.JournalistsNewspapers, magazines and online services may hire journalists to investigate and report on people or events. Journalists must be able to write quickly, effectively and meet deadlines.Nonfiction Book WritersNonfiction book writers typically work with book publishers or other businesses on freelance or contract basis. They often write general-knowledge or technical books on an almost limitless range of subjects. Nonfiction book writing often, but not always, requires the author to possess specialized knowledge of the subject field. This is particularly true for technical writers. Nonfiction book writers are rarely members of a writing staff, but instead are hired to write one book at a time.Other writing categories include translators, screenwriters, reviewers, speechwriters, columnists and game writers. And, of course, novelists. PURSUE A FORMAL EDUCATION:A formal education is not required to be a professional writer, although a solid degree in a writing-related discipline can hold tremendous value. Completing college-level coursework at the post-secondary level helps to hone writing skills. Writers seeking a formal education should consider degree programs in English, the humanities or creative writing on both the bachelor’s and master’s levels. Quality, fully-accredited degree programs are available at most reputable colleges and universities in the United States, as well as online. Most colleges have school newspapers and magazines where students can research, write and publish stories and articles. Many schools also offer internships in cooperation with local newspapers, magazines and advertising agencies. WRITE ON SPEC AND COMPILE A PORTFOLIO:The key to improving your writing and getting hired as a professional is to write. It is unlikely that someone is going to hire a writer without any previous experience or presentable work. Therefore, most aspiring writers begin writing in their chosen area on “spec,” that is, for no pay or certainty that their work will be published. Spec writers can (and should) shop their completed work around in the hope that someone will purchase it, but it is more likely that a quality spec piece will lead to being hired to write something new. GET AN AGENT OR MANAGER:One of the biggest hurdles for a writer, particularly a novelist or screenwriter, to overcome is finding a publisher or producer to read his or her work. In many cases, publishers and producers refuse to read any material that is not submitted to them through an agent or manager. Unfortunately, getting an agent to read your work can be tough without a little know-how. Therefore, if you have a personal connection to an agency, use it. If not, start by sending out query letters either by email or traditional mail. Never submit your novel or screenplay with your query, but only when you are asked to by the agent. And never submit any material until you are confident it is of professional quality. If you think that a career in writing is a good match for you, you may be curious as to what kind of salary to expect. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics America, the median annual wage for authors and writers was $55, 940 in 2012. Income amounts vary depending on the type of writing position. Technical writers tend to earn the highest salaries. Freelance writers are usually responsible for paying their own health insurance and pension.

The first step is to be perfectly happy with writing as a non-career. As with most creative endeavors, success is far from guaranteed. However, if it’s truly something you desire then this shouldn’t stop you. It won’t stop you. There is a possibility that at the end of your life, you may have amassed a lifetime of work and writing that nobody has read outside of your friends and family. It’s a possibility that no decent amount of people will ever read it, let alone like it, period. Once you’ve made peace with this fact, you’re ready to write. The second step is simple: Write. It doesn’t matter what you’re writing, but practice. Set a goal for yourself with regards to the amount of writing. If you write screenplays, commit to writing one page a day towards an established story or perhaps brainstorming one new concept. The same with novels, or perhaps one blog post a day, so on and so forth. Even conservatively, let’s say that 80% of it is crap, 15% of it is passable, 4% of it is good, and 1% of it is gold. Once you’re used to churning out material, you can find that golden yarn, identify it, and tug on it a little further. Perhaps it’s a certain tone, a certain approach, or a particular idea you think is golden. Find it through practicing, and then pursue it. The third step: Share. While the only guaranteed fulfillment is that of pursuing your own creative ends, ultimately we all want to be able to share our creative visions with others. Share your work with family, friends, coworkers, strangers on the internet, whoever. You have only seen a small portion of the human experience, and reinterpreting your own work through the lens of others can actually provide for a more meaningful work. It’s painful and personal, but it’s crucial. Lars Ulrich of Metallica, who is not the traditional paradigm of creativity I realize, once had a very helpful point to make with creativity. In crafting songs, it was never a singular process from start to finish. The best songs the band had crafted were analogous to a match of tennis. Somebody has an idea and ‘serves’ it, spurring creativity in somebody else who returns it, and this process continues ad infinitum. The process is different for everybody, but find somebody to share the process with. The fourth step: Tweak. You’re probably feeling differently about your original work, good. Don’t scrap it, save it. But start creating iterations of it. Writing something final can often feel like a dark room where one has to stumble around to find the furniture. Over time, you can eventually start to feel out the locations of the major pieces and assemble an accurate picture of the whole. While having a broad mindset and juggling projects may actually be helpful to the process at previous points, during this step I would recommend a monomaniacal approach. Laser in to what the essence of your story is, what do you have to leave in to keep the core of the piece and what can you remove? This process of tweaking helps you identify the purpose and thusly refine it. Wash, rinse, and repeat prior steps 2, 3, and 4. The fifth step (optional): Business The art of pitching, making connections, and so forth is beyond the scope of this post. However, without proper hustle the best stories will never get exposure. I wish I could help with this part more but I’m sure there are other sections on Quora that answer this. Disclaimer: this is what I have seen interacting with other writers and what has worked the best for me with the creative process. Everybody’s process is different and best of luck!

WRITE.Then... WRITE MORE.Then... WRITE EVEN MORE! The career part comes from finding someone to pay you for writing. That is going to vary widely across the niches and fields and genres. What do you want to write, and for who? My advice is kinda structured towards feature writing, but can be interpreted to fit current news or fiction.You will want to get hugely successful, of course, but before then you have to pay your metaphorical dues. You'll have to write boring bad stuff, and you'll have to approach strangers, but as you work you'll develop a network of contacts.You should absolutely start with a writing class. Talk to your library or local educational facility. Then you'll write bad stuff that no one cares about. This might be for your class's publication, or for something you found on textbroker.com or fiverr.com or craigslist or elance. You'll start at the bottom of the food-chain, writing website filler content and ad copy that no one wants to read. This will give you good practice dealing with requirements and deadlines and research and all that. Once you've worked your way up within those sites, you'll start finding better assignments and being able to do better work. Much of this work will be ghost writing blogs. This is not really getting published - but it is selling your writing. Maybe, with some of that under your belt, you can find a blog or site that is willing to post your work under your own name. This is the lowest form of publication, so congratulations on making it this far!You can also work on your own blog. If you do this, and want to show it off, you'll need quality content, a professional look, and consistent postings. Take it seriously.Then you can find a real publication. Local newspapers and magazines, blogs and art circles in your region, and whatever else catches your eye. Send them samples of your work and tell them why they should pay you to write for them (there are often editorial points-of-contact, or submission guidelines, so be sure to follow their protocols).Work your way up the publications within your area. Start with the free local paper - then get into the daily that people actually have to pay for. Do the same with local suburb magazines, working towards the big glossy publication named after your city.Now you can start looking for regional or national work. This is where a portfolio of published work, and a network of editors, becomes important. Ask around, and show your stuff, and be willing to work hard.Good luck! Alternatively you can write something huge (expose, novel, screenplay) and try really hard to find someone to buy it, but even this will be easier if you have publication experience (for your own practice as well as for proving that you're worth their time). A network of editors and publications will help you here, too, because it'll get you in touch with people you wouldn't otherwise find, and will help you learn about various opportunities. Good luck!

When I was sixteen I was an aspiring author with a nearly-complete manuscript. I’d already managed to meet several semi-famous wordsmiths at launches, signings, classes. I’d been told, ‘Write what you know!’ and 'Show, don’t tell!’ and once, memorably, 'The road to hell is paved with adverbs.’ But the very best suggestion came from a writer named Brendan Mackie. He was a dishevelled but fresh-faced hippie-type with a faint North American accent, often found performing poetry at indie music festivals held in vacant dance studios. He’d usually be sandwiched on the program between a teenage ska band and an acapella hip hop group. His words—and the passion with which he recited them—always left the audience spellbound. I sometimes saw him selling monochromatic hand-photocopied and stapled books of his poems on street-corners around Canberra. I was at the launch of Mackie’s first book of short stories—Lonely In Crowds—which had proper binding and an actual publisher’s name on the spine. I was awed. This was somehow more impressive than the work of the famous writers I had met, who presumably had decades of grooming at posh universities in New York or Paris. Brendan Mackie was a guy not much older than me. We lived in the same town. We had been to some of the same schools. How had he done this? After the speeches, I approached him and asked for advice. How could I become him? 'Well, first, you gotta join a writers centre,’ he said. Before I heard those words, I hadn’t known writers centres existed. (I suspect many aspiring authors don’t.) Perhaps this is because they are usually not-for-profits, scraping by on tiny budgets and using every dollar to provide services to their members rather than to advertise themselves. Or maybe it’s because writers—including me, these days—like to pretend that they are naturally gifted rather than taught. I wish more authors were like Mackie. We are constantly asked for advice, and 'Join a writers centre’ is the most useful thing we could possibly say. It’s more practical than 'Write what you know’ or 'Use the active voice’ because a writers centre will teach them those things, and more. Writers centres provide workshops, manuscript assessments, mentorships, researcher accommodation. They provide a place for writers to research books, launch them, or just hang out and critique one another’s work. A university will charge you $20,000 for a creative writing degree. A writers centre will charge you $65 dollars a year, and any profits will be spent helping other writers. Last I heard, Brendan Mackie was teaching English in Istanbul. I hope his students know how lucky they are. Yes, I still have my battered copy of Lonely In Crowds. No, you can’t borrow it.

Back in 2017, I saw a friend talking about freelancing and I was baffled. Back then, I didn’t know what freelancing was, or how people made money from it. The concept was totally new to me, and thankfully I’ve learned about it then. At first, I didn’t know what to do, nor how to start. I didn’t know what to search, nor what talent I had. My mind was completely blank, and that’s how it was for about 2 months. Then I decided to start translating, a month after, I realized translating wasn’t for me and I turned to writing. Writing just seemed to come naturally to me, and so I started freelance writing. At first, I was freelance writing part-time, but then, I gradually started writing more and now that I finished studies, I’m finally able to work full-time. But, I’m going to be completely honest, it wasn’t easy to start freelancing. It wasn’t easy to land jobs, and get people to hire me at first. Every time I applied for a job, I’d get asked if I had any experience, and every time the answer was the same. I didn’t have a lot of experience back then, I still didn’t have any articles published in my name, and I still wasn’t popular. So, it was quite hard to start a writing career from scratch. But that didn’t stop me and look where I am at now. So, you’re probably wondering the same. You’ve probably wondered how to start a writing career once too many time but still didn’t get the answer. And I’m here to finally show you how. How To Start A Writing Career Starting a writing career isn’t all sunshine and good vibes. It can be quite hectic at first as a lot of people would want examples of your writing skills and proof that you’re a good writer. Some will want to pay you peanuts for long-format articles and for even eBooks, and some will want free article tests. Some won’t like your work, and some will tell you that you’re better off without writing. What’s important is that you remind yourself day after day of why you’re doing what you’re doing. There are going to be a lot of downs, but also a lot of ups that will help you with the pain. So, now that I’m done speaking like a coach, let’s get to the “how to start a writing career” question. I’m going to give you access to a number of steps which you’ll have to follow one by one if you want to become a writer. So, here goes nothing. Step Number 1: Specialize Or Generalize A lot of bloggers wonder if they should specialize or generalize, and honestly, you should ask yourself that question as well. A general writer is a good way to start before you find out what you like writing about. It’s also a great way to make income on the short and long term, a lot of writers choose to stay general writers even after long years of experience. But I personally recommend specializing. A lot of people will hire a specialized writer than a general writer any day. That’s because specialized writers know what they’re doing and what they’re talking about, unlike general ones who have to do research. They also know what tone and what things to say, and that is why specialized writers are paid better than general writers. Although the opportunities for work are not as many as the one general writers have, you can still make a full income of specialized writing. Step Number 2: Build A Portfolio A lot of other bloggers will ask you to start applying for jobs but I’m going to say wait. First, you’ll have to build a portfolio. A portfolio is the first thing clients are going to ask you about. You’ll need to have examples of your writings ready by the time the clients ask you or even by the time you apply to your first job. To build a portfolio from scratch, it’ll be quite easy. Here are all the things you should do: Create pieces of writing from your own imagination.Rewrite existing articles.Criticize pieces that already exist out there.Enhance pieces that already exist out there.By doing this, you’ll have a rich portfolio that you can show your fist client. Having a portfolio, even if is only filled with samples written on “google doc”, will make you seem more professional than those new writers who don’t. Step Number 3: Research Your Potential Clients’ Needs This is something I do when I have quite some free time on my hand. What I do is go to writing forums or subreddits and see what potential clients say. I take a look at what they’re saying, I analyze their needs, I see their past experiences with freelance writers, and I build a base of information from there. I try to find out how I can enhance my writing skills based on their experiences and opinions. I also take a look at what they like to see on cover letters, on resumes, and on portfolios. I apply all of these tips on the next job application I do, and I usually get amazing results. Step Number 4: Start Applying For Jobs If you do all of this, then you’re ready for the next step of how to start a writing career. And it’s applying for jobs. If you created a portfolio, learned what potential clients expect from you, and have chosen a niche or two, then you can easily start looking for jobs. Look for all the job opportunities that exist either on: Freelance writing sites like ContenaFreelance platforms like UpworkSocial mediaCold pitchingLinkedInThese platforms will help you find a job even as a beginner and will help you build a successful writing career slowly, but steadily. Step Number 4: Start Building Your Experience If you start applying for jobs, then you can finally start building your experience. It’s not going to be easy at first, but it’s going to be worth it. What helped me improve in writing is mainly my job experiences. I had clients that have helped me learn new things about new domains including SEO. I had clients help me enhance my writing skills. I had clients that have made my work get published, and so on. So, the best thing that can help you become a professional writer, is to get jobs. ..Read More.

It depends on what kind of writer - ghostwriter, journalist, copywriter, poet, non-fiction writer, fiction writer? All those paths are slightly different. That said, as somebody with a side business of fiction writing, I found three factors very helpful: acquiring the skills, actually doing it (versus talking about it), and doing a lot of it for a long time (aka consistency). The skills will allow you to produce text that people want to read and pay for. There are many writers who already fail at this hurdle. Writing is a pretty complex set of skills, and you learn it by observation, trial and error, and feedback (from editors and/or mentors). Actually doing it will set you apart from all the people talking about writing - the “I have a book in me” crowd. Yeah, I have one (or a hundred) in me to, but the difference is I’m actually letting it out. Which means sitting down and spending hundreds of hours on talking to people that never existed except in my head and agonizing over whether I should trash chapter 4 or where I can tell the story the way I see/hear/feel it. And yes, that can mean getting up early, not going out with friends every day, and not watching all the content on Netflix, because I’ll be up in my study, working. Then, one book won’t (likely) change your life. Careers are built on doing it all year, every year, just like a job in the office. I aim to write 3 new novels a year, and I have about 70 stories written so far, not all of which are still available, but they all earn me a little every month, leading to a second income over time. Good luck!

Write lots! Ok that’s a bit too brief, but it’s true. Like any other muscle, the more you flex your writing one, the stronger it gets. There are lots of ways to do this — it can be really useful to set yourself a challenge of writing a certain amount every day (there are tools that help you do this, like 750 Words - Write every day. and others), and the act of just sitting down and making yourself write, whatever it says, however it reads, will help more than anything else I can think of. I started my writing career by having a blog, and sitting down and writing endless amounts about the most boring things that happened to me that day. That was how I found my voice though, just writing and writing and not caring if anyone was reading. There comes a point though where you have to learn how to edit that — to give feedback to others, and to receive feedback on how you can do better. Be prepared at some point to give what you have to someone you admire and ask for their feedback — ask them to give you things that you can work on though, not nit-picking, but broad constructive advice is always better structured as “tell me what you’d like to hear more about, and where I lost your interest, because that’s a good indicator of what isn’t working.” But mainly? Write lots. :)

Before you even think of any qualifications, you should start to journal. Try to fill out one journal per month - write down words you like, diary entries, poems, prose, fragments of conversations you hear on the commute to work, memories you never want to forget, your dreams … Take time to write every day. Become it. If you haven’t already, set up a blog or website, get your name and work out there. Attend poetry readings, maybe even reach out and see if there’s any local coffee shops, theatres etc that would let you share your work. Send your poetry, prose or script into local competitions too, anything to get yourself noticed. Education-wise, it is really helpful to take classes at a university. Of course many writers haven’t done this, can’t do this (financial reasons) and of course it isn’t vital. But for example, I am in the UK and we get student loans so I have been able to attend uni. The university I am graduating from has a lot of ties with local establishments and agencies, and there’s a lot of professional writers who can guide you. I am applying for the masters in creative writing as I too would like to pursue a career in writing. A lot of it is word of mouth so it’s important to try to mix in with the poetry / prose community, even if this isn’t through the uni route. It’s really difficult to get yourself out there and it takes a lot of confidence but as said and quoted from The Rocky Horror Picture Show: “Don’t dream it, be it” Best of luck

First, figure out what genre you want to write in: i.e. Drama, fiction. Sci-fi, fantasy, Romance, etc, etc. Then discover or develop a style of writing and your own voice. Figure out whether your writing material is more message driven or experience driven, or about raising awareness to issues that you believe so strongly in that your audience needs to know about it. Following this, do your best to avoid cliched writing: i.e. writing stories that have already been told before, because more often than not, new writers end up taking the easy way out and believe that what they are writing is unique and will get famous for this, which is simply not true. A perfect example of this is writing the typical boy meets girl story with what is perceived to be a different angle when it isn’t. Before you even write down a single word down on a piece of white paper, ask yourself, is your idea unique enough for your audience to be vested in? Is your idea commercially viable (if you are serious about writing and want to make a career out of it)? Practice writing. The more you write, the better you get at the craft of creative writing. Improve on what you have already written, because you don’t simply write once and be done with that particular written works. When you submit for feedback, the reader (be it a friend or a stranger), he or she will let you know what he/she doesn’t understand or when they point out problems in what you have written. The key to successful writers is to keep writing and improving on what you’ve previously written until you get it right. When you get the worn out advice of: “write what you know”, question it. You really should be writing what you don’t know that interests you or something that inspired you that you don’t know much about. This will encourage you to go out and do some research it. And finally, join a writers group of some sort that is established in your area. It doesn’t have to be well established, but a group that you find and or feel will give you useful feedback and encourages quality writing while cherishing your creativity. You don’t want to sacrifice either the way the producers in big business may want you to. Be creative and always strive to put out quality work or your best foot forward as another saying goes.

I want to eventually pursue a career in writing. How should I start? Hmmm … what kind of writing? Journalism — i.e. nonfiction articles and reporting? Novels of fiction? Instructional material? Without specifics in your question, you will not get specific answers. The “uneducated natural” is a fiction created to support entertaining stories. The ignorant NEVER perform well. As with all careers, you therefore start by obtaining the right kind of education. Have you taken any writing courses? Have you sufficiently mastered the language in which you hope to publish? After all, words are the tools you use to create a work of art. Knowing the mechanics of writing and how one constructs the type of writing that interests you is a good beginning. Be aware that the writing courses that teach you to write for actual publishing are rare. You will still have much to learn. Beyond that, it is a matter of practice and getting up that learning curve. Get up the learning curve. Write about what you know (or it won’t be credible). Write, write, and write some more. Create a work and then set it aside for at least a month. Then maybe you can evaluate it more objectively and see it from the reader’s perspective instead of the writer’s perspective. Critique it, then revise it, or trash it and start over. Learn to eliminate all the words you can while still making your point. I am not a fan of writers’ workshops. Skip them, as they are full of other junior writers who create questionable critiques — a case of the blind leading the blind. Once you have something that satisfies you, submit it to appropriate publishing companies. Web based publishing is more open to unknown and junior authors, so start there. Learn to abide by their stylistic requirements. Especially at first, the responses to your submissions will be nothing at all or the occasional rejection slip. Write a lot. Practice makes perfect! You don’t have to have a complete idea to get started either. You can start off with short blog articles or short stories. Writing whatever comes to your mind is a great way to figure out who you are as a writer—your interests, your narrative style, your voice. Don’t be afraid to write. You might be afraid to pick up the pen because you think you’ll suck. That’s okay. Every single first draft sucks. And along those lines, don’t be afraid to edit either. Once you start getting the hang of writing, you might go back to earlier pieces and thing “wow, this is awful, it needs a complete overhaul” and that’s perfectly okay—in fact, it’s great, because it shows you’ve improved as a writer! So don’t be afraid to start and suck at it, because it’s the first step toward getting better at something. The only truly bad first draft is one that is blank. Read crafting books and articles. These will help you learn how to craft a novel or an article or whatever type of writing it is you’re interested in. Just for the sake of this answer, I’ll stick with novels. Anyone can slap together a story and call it a day, but some of the crucial things that make a story work are structure, and character and plot arcs. Of course this is a gross oversimplification—as a writer, we do a lot of fiddly bits behind the scenes that readers never actually see. I know writers who will outline, who will create extensive chapter maps, who will set goals in their books to make sure they hit the inciting incident 5% into their novel, if not sooner. All these are tools that the writer uses, but not necessarily something that the reader will ever see. Do your homework. Whatever you choose to write, whether it’s fiction or non-fiction, do your homework. If it’s non-fiction, then obviously do a ton of research. For fiction, it may depend on the genre, but generally, most fiction books will also require a certain degree of homework. Sci-fi, in particular. You don’t want to sink hours and hours into developing a virus for you world only to find out that that isn’t actually how viruses work at all and you have to change some critical elements and upend all that work. If you decide to include characters from marginalized/minority backgrounds, do your homework. Find out everything you possibly can about the group your character comes from, and if you’re able to, find authenticity readers—real life people from those groups who can read your work and tell you if you’re getting the details right. Don’t write alone. Writing sounds like it’s probably a solitary activity, but in fact there are tons of communities where writers can support one another. Look for local groups in your town, or if you can’t, there are tons of online communities you can join. Wattpad, for one, is a great place to host your work if you’re looking for light feedback and to bond with other authors who are also just starting out (mostly.) Look for critique partners—I actually found mine through Twitter. They can turn a critical eye on your manuscript and point out areas where they feel you need improvement. Together, you can all help each other improve and hopefully land one of those ever elusive publishing deals. Read. Kind of in-line with the crafting books, but this is just advice to read broadly. Read in your genre, read outside your genre. And when you read, don’t just passively absorb the story—study the book’s structure and characters and voice. Once you start writing and learning the craft, you’ll be able to pick out how other authors are putting their stories together. You’ll be able to see xyz motivates a character, and how that motivation fuels them to reach their goal, despite the conflicts that stand in the way. You’ll notice when act I ends and act II begins. You’ll be able to figure out exactly where the inciting incident occurs and why it is that particular scene that kicks off the story and not some other.

The best way is to learn your craft. Start out small and work up. The man on top of the mountain didn’t just fall there. Things take time. If you wanted to fly a plane, what would you do? You'd find a ground school and take lessons. If you wanted to play the piano, what would you do? You'd find a piano teacher and take classes. What makes writing any different? Writing is an art, but it’s a learned art. To ask someone how to write a story is like asking “How do I climb a mountain?” You don’t, unless you’ve had the training. And no, it’s not rocket science, but writing is something that needs to be studied and practiced. Anybody can sit down and write crap. You see it all the time in self pubbed books. Most people will tell you to just start writing, and keep writing, but I don't agree. It's not enough to just write every day if you don't know what you're doing or how to improve something. That just means days and weeks and months of useless writing. It's like not knowing how to knit so you just keep making loops with the yarn. You can't get better, you can't turn that into a scarf ... you have the desire, but you don't know how. I'm going to give you my stock answer that I give everyone who asks me this question. I'm going to give you some good advice on how to learn the craft, and give you a place to send in some of your work when you're ready. In order to write stories that people want to read you will need to understand how to put one together. There is a definite pattern and rhythm to it. And there are certain expectations from the editors and publishing houses as to how your story is laid out. You will need a good imagination, one that can look at a situation and picture all sorts of different scenarios. You need to be able to ask 'what if' and come up with twists and lines that are new and fresh. You will need to be able to research things. For example I wrote a story set in Iran where there was a wedding. I had to research how the wedding would take place, the food, the customs, common Iranian names, clothing, etc. in order to write an interesting yet correct story. Take classes in writing; grammar and punctuation (very important... lots of self published books are swimming in glaring errors and typos), character building, dialogue, plotting, pacing, point of view (POV), inner and outer conflicts, subplots, scenes and sequels, genres, story boards, twists, chapter hooks, suspense, killer opening lines, and satisfying endings. If you're going to write sci-fi you will need to take classes in world building. Each genre of book has its own set of expectations from the reader that you will need to fulfill. For example a murder mystery must have clues for the reader to try and solve. A romance needs a happen ever after ending, known to writers as an HEA. A thriller needs fast pacing and danger. There are classes in short story writing. Where to find these classes? Local community colleges often offer writing classes. My local library has classes seasonally. Best of all there are hundreds of classes you can take on-line. They run about $25-$35 each and range from 2 to 4 weeks. Google on-line writing classes and you will get lots of sites. Try www.oirwa.com or www.savvyauthors.com. They have classes year round. You don’t have to join either one but if you do you get a discount on their classes. Just because a class might be about writing romances, writing is writing; many of the same principles apply to other genres. So don’t hesitate to take a course on character building or writing scenes just because the site caters to romance. There are sites that offer expensive classes, so be careful. I’d recommend starting with a few less expensive ones to see if you really like writing and want to continue. IMO it is not necessary to have a degree or to take an expensive course to write well. Read a lot. Get a feel for how a story is told; how it starts, how it progresses through the story to a satisfying end. See how your favorite author keeps you interested. I don't know your age, but when you are able join some writing groups, even online groups are helpful. Oftentimes these groups offer lectures and classes in writing. They share their work and critique each other. Once you start taking classes and get a good feel for how to put a story together, write some short stories (800 - 1500 words). The more you write, the better you will become. You will make new writer mistakes, we all did. But that's how you learn. I say start with short stories because they are, well short, and don't take years to complete like a novel does. You can share your stories with others and get feedback. Take the feedback and use what you feel is constructive for you and ignore the others. Some people don't give good feedback, or there is a motive behind their negative comments. You have to learn which ones to take and learn from and which ones to disregard. And when you are reading and critiquing other's stories, be kind, give good feedback, and find something positive to say to them. It's hard to hear harsh things about your writing. It's tough love. But it works when you get it and understand why the comment was made and you go and make your piece better because of it. Submitting to contests is another way to get good feedback because the judges are usually editors and agents who have their finger on the pulse of good writing that sells. Once you feel you have written a great short story, be brave and submit it to a magazine that publishes fiction in the genre you wrote. Don't worry about rejections. They will come. Oftentimes it's not because your story is not good, it's because the story doesn't fit their needs. To make a career out of writing… Well, I can’t speak as someone who’s been there, done that. However, I can speak as someone else who has wondered about that question. I went through a phase where I wanted to write novels for a living, for about three months. And I wrote some great stuff during that time, which I still enjoy going back and reading, wondering how each of those half-finished drafts would end. I didn’t know I could write like that before I started, and it’s time I don’t regret spending. But I put the rest of my life on hold. Family, friends, study - they didn’t matter to me. I was going to be a writer, and I was going to write a famous novel, and after that I would live comfortably and my family would all look up to me. It sounds childish, I’m sure, but probably familiar. Looking back, I prefer the way I go now. I have a solid future. I’m in no way dependent on the gamble of success, and I know it. I still write a lot, mostly in the evenings. I write a lot of fanfics, and when I post some of them, I get positive feedback. Writing is not my career. It’s my hobby. One day, this might change, but I won’t be heartbroken if it doesn’t. Writing is now something I do for fun. I enjoy it.
